bibl.title: Letter from Robert Carter to John Starke, September 4, 1723

div1.p: Robert Carter writes to Glasgow merchant John Starke, September 4, 1723, reminding the merchant that he shipped 51 hogsheads on board Capt. Bowman's ship and that he hopes for a better price for it than last year's. He orders cloth, sugar, and boots, and will add claret, burgundy, and champagne provided his tobacco sells at a price that he specifies.

div1.head: Letter from Robert Carter to John Starke, September 4, 1723

opener.dateline:
Rappahannock, [Lancaster County, Virginia]
Sepr, 4th. 1723—
Mr. Jno. Starke

div1.p:
My last went by Capt. Bowman Accompd.
a Bill of Lading for Fifty one hogsheads of Tobo. This by Capt.
Ben with Mr. Read Covers A Bill of Lading for 23 hogsheads
More, I carried It to the Ship Side & chose rather to send In Your
Ship than any other purely to Oblige You, I hope You'l be able
to Advance It to a much higher price than You did last Year
that We may be Encouragd to Continue our business Yor. way
I have now 40 hogsheads more that I design to Your port, here are
Sevl. Ships that Yet want Freight, but I'm Almost come to
A resolution that I will Ship no more this Year, being Morally
Assurd Tobo. must Advance here the next, Mr. Reid hath a
very good knowledge of the Country & will give You the best
Accot. of the Poor Crops we are like to make

I have Already writ to You for a hhd of Clarret & a
Qr. Cask of French Brandy For Mrs. Burwell, I now desire You
to Send me in Two hundred yds. of Yor. Cource Gallow shields
Yd. Wide Cloth wch. You say costs from 14 to 15d. per Yd. one hundred
Wte. of Your best double refind Sugr. & two pr of Boots for my
Own Wear to be between 12s. & 13s. Size one pr to be half
Jacks for Winter. the Other pair to be Sumr. Boots I have
spoke to Mr Reid to Assist in buying these Boots Who I
believe will best know how to please me—

And now I will be so Prodigall upon Condition You can
make of my Tobo. round £5/20s per hogshead [illegible] to Order You to
Send me in a hogshead of the best Clarret upon for My own Accot. use &
Six Doz. Qts. of Burgundy & as much Champaigne but upon
no less termes will I spend any money upon these easie wanted Liqrs.
I drank both of Collo. Page's Champaigne & Burgundy which
provd Extraordinary good, I am
div1.closer:
Sir
Yor. very humble Servt
per the Charles of Glasgow.

div1.head: NOTES
div1.note: Source copy consulted: Robert Carter letter book, 1723 June 16-1724 April 23, Robert Carter Papers (acc. no. 3807), Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia.

Robert Carter generally used a return address of "Rappahannock" for the river on which he lived rather than "Corotoman," the name of his home, on his correspondence, especially to merchants abroad. The county and colony have been added for clarity.

[1] John Stark was a merchant, probably the one to whom Carter referred when he wrote to Micajah Perry on1723 July 4 that he had drawn an order on "Mr. Stark of Glasgow." On that same day, he wrote to a John Stark, referring to Captain Bowman.
[2] Captain Samuel Bowman commanded the Lucia. Carter mentioned this vessel in his diary in June 1724, and again on 1726 March 4 when he wrote that she "came in had 20 Weeks Passage."

[3] James Read (Reid) is not referred to as "captain" which means he was an official of John Stark's firm on a trading vessel who was empowered to do its business in Virginia. He was aboard the Charles, a Glasgow ship that was owned by Stark, by which this letter was sent.
[4] It has not been determined at this time (5/16/02) what type of cloth Carter is ordering.

[5] A half-jack was a boot ending below the knee with turned down top of a softer and lighter colored leather, pulled on by leather or string loops on each side. (William W. Burke, "Dictionary of 18th Century Clothing Terms" [www.nwta.com/patterns/pdfs/111dict.pdf, found on line 5/9/02])
